bibl.title: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, October 16, 1940

div1.p: Moran describes his discussions with the Cubans on the proposed Lazear Memorial.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, October 16, 1940
div1.opener:
Havana, Oct. 16, 1940.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
MAYO CLINIC,
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
This afternoon I sought Dr. Albertini in the secluded office
which he has maintained for years at Calle Habana No. 6. My object was
to seek his good offices to the end that Dr. Domingo Ramos, (Secretary of
Defense when you were here and renamed as “Minister of Defense” in Pres.
Batista's new Ministry, he being the only member of the retiring Cabinet
to be taken on in the new) voluntarily admit that the “False Camp Lazear”
was not the “Real Camp Lazear”. I carried to Rojas “Journal” with me
to convince Dr. Albertini of the legitimacy of the “Finca San José” site.
Imagine my surprise to find in Dr. Albertini's waiting room Sr. Giberga,
Dr. Ramos' private secretary and Aide. While awaiting my turn to see Dr.
Albertini, I showed the entries to Sr. Giberga but before I got to the last
of the entries in Dr. Rojas' own handwriting, out came Dr. Ramos from the
Sanctum Santorum of Dr. Albertini, expressing pleasure at seeing me. As
always, he was in a great hurry but he stayed with me long enough to hear
of our discoveries, including that of the original Building No. 1. He is
perfectly agreeable to have the building transferred to the “False Camp
Lazear” but, as near as I could guess, he has no intention of setting up
any form of memorial there without using “Campamento de Lazear” in some
manner as part and parcel of the projected memorial. He told me to con-
sult with you and get your ideas as to a number of names, or one that you
might consider ideal, for the projected memorial. He asked me how you
would like to have it called “Instituto Lazear”, for instance. He told
it was the intention of the Government to erect a building on the acquired
site for the investigation of tropical diseases and that the memorial would
be an exclusively “Lazear Memorial”; that it would not be a memorial to
the Yellow Fever Board nor to Finlay. From that I infer that a bronze
plaque or other form of tablet or slab would be placed in the Memorial
and that the names of the four members of the Board, with that of Finlay,
would appear thereon, in either marble or bronze. The important thing
is, so far as Americans are concerned, as to the wording which might
eventually be adopted. Lazear's martyrdom is acknowledged by the Cubans
and heartily so because the names of Lazear and Finlay have never been
in conflict when it comes to the point of determining the respective
shares of Reed and Finlay in “THE CONQUEST OF YELLOW FEVER”. For the sake
of harmony and to the end that Cubans may not be prejudiced in advance
against your book in formation, I think your attitude from now on should
be of directed towards “ceding” and “making allowances” so that, when your
story is published in book form, you may not be classified as “one sided”.
As you well know, I am extremely anxious that the “Conquest of Yellow
Fever” should be published, after its text has been assembled and edited
in a STRICTLY IMPARTIAL manner. That you can do that job, I am most con-
fident. You are an investigator and analyst of no mean calibre and in the
past month I have mentally grumbled at your thoroughness, not because I
begrudge the time and effort but because, unfortunately, I cannot devote
enough time to the task, having business duties to attend to. Having
always being a stickler for accuracy and detail, I could not trust Mrs. P.
to take care of the letters, notes, observations and data which I have
sent you in the past three weeks. I have had to drum them out on the
typewriter with two index fingers, many times re-writing full pages of
single space material after finding, upon re-reading what I had written,
that the result was far from clarifying.

I am sending a copy of this letter to General Kean and will
more than likely see him at Virginia. We will discuss the matter of
names for the eventual Memorial and I am sure any recommendation of
General Kean's to the Cuban authorities will be carefully weighed and,
more than likely, given exceptional consideration. He is very highly
respected by every member of the Cuban medical profession and those who
knew him well honor and revere him. I am sure you will have every
ounce of support from him towards the success of your laudable mission
in this entire matter.

“Quinta Durañon”, General Lee's Headquarters, in Marianao, has
no visible number on it, it being known all over Havana, without a number.
The caretaker, however, told me that it was 115. It is two long blocks
and a half distant from General Lee Street (about four average blocks).
Will drop you a few lines again tomorrow by AIRMAIL.
